newsitem.title: JAPAN: Nissan Life woes not to affect insurer ratings - S&P.
newsitem.headline: Nissan Life woes not to affect insurer ratings - S&P.

text.p: Standard & Poor's Corp said on Wednesday that unrated Nissan Mutual Life Insurance Co's failure would not result in rating changes for other Japanese insurers.

But the Japanese authorities' closure of Nissan Life last week will test the adequacy of the industry's 200-billion-yen policyholder guarantee fund and may result in a rise in cancellations of insurers' savings contracts, it said.
S&P said that it would monitor the pressure on liquidity for the industry in general and for individual market participants.

S&P said that its 1997 Japanese Life Insurance Digest, to be released at the end of May, shows a growing disparity between financially strong companies and weaker ones. This will be illustrated by the very broad range of ratings assigned, it said.

The digest says Japanese life insurers' poorly structured products and rudimentary asset-liability management practices have strained earnings, increased the volatility of their earnings and worsened their balance sheet structures, S&P said.

The digest also says that competition from new entrants and emerging consumerism sparked by the removal of regulatory barriers, coupled with the recent failure of Nissan Life, will test the resilience of companies' business franchises and greatly affect how companies structure and deliver products, S&P said.
